The Shadowdusk family motto used to be "No secrets without truth." After the family's fall, its motto changed to "We do not fear the darkness." The family's crest is a lit torch with three embers rising from the flame, set against a purple background. In the wake of the family's descent into Undermountain and madness, this crest has been literally turned upside down, so that the torch flame points downward.

entries.name: Star Spawn
entries: Creatures from the Far Realm visit Shadowdusk Hold from time to time. If you have a copy of {@book Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes|MTF}, you can add one or more star spawn from that book to the roster of creatures encountered on this level of Undermountain.

entries.name: Dezmyr and Zalthar
entries: The current leaders of Shadowdusk Hold are the twins {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|wdmm|Dezmyr} and {@creature Zalthar Shadowdusk|wdmm}. They have remained close throughout life and undeath, and might have led their mortal family skillfully if circumstances had played out differently.
The twins are devoted to each other and are obsessed with returning their family to prominence and ultimately seizing control of Waterdeep.

entries.name: Exploring This Level
entries: All location descriptions for this level are keyed to map 22.
The following features apply throughout Shadowdusk Hold unless otherwise noted in an area's description:

items: The hold consists of three tiers. Ceilings in rooms and hallways are 15 feet high unless stated otherwise. The floors are smooth stone polished to a mirror finish.

Any humanoid that dies in Shadowdusk Hold rises from its corpse {@dice 1d4} hours later as a {@creature will-o'-wisp} under the DM's control. Casting {@spell dispel evil and good} on the corpse before the will-o'-wisp forms prevents such an occurrence, as does bringing the body out of Shadowdusk Hold or into the area of a {@spell hallow} spell.
Sconces throughout Shadowdusk Hold flicker with torchlight created by {@spell continual flame} spells. These magic torches are set in upside-down sconces, and their magical flames point downward.

entries.name: Tier 1
entries: The uppermost tier of Shadowdusk Hold closely resembles the style and architecture of the family manor in Waterdeep before it was destroyed. This section of the hold resembles a mausoleum. The Far Realm's influence on this tier is faint.
Two members of the Shadowdusk family reside here: a wizard named {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM} and her mad husband, Derrion.

entries.name: 1. Grand Foyer
entries: The stairs from {@adventure level 21|WDMM|21} descend to a grand entry chamber that contains the following features:
{@b Pillars}. Pillars support the 40-foot-high, vaulted ceiling.
{@b Grells}. Six {@creature Grell||grells} float behind the pillars to the north. The grells attack visitors and can use their tentacles to open and close doors as needed.

{@b Apparitions}. Spectral images of dead servants and adventurers occasionally fade into view, wander the hall, then fade away. These images are harmless regional effects created by Halaster (see "{@area Halaster's Lair|bb9|x}").
{@b Statues}. Statues depicting two well-dressed humans stand in alcoves to the south.

The statues show the Shadowdusk twins, Zalthar and Dezmyr, as they appeared in life. Zalthar's statue is in the west alcove and stands 6 feet 11 inches tall. Dezmyr's statue to the east stands 6 feet 3 inches tall. An inscription on the bottom of each statue identifies its subject.

entries.name: 2. Twisted Gallery

entries: {@b Bas-Reliefs}. The curved walls are lined with bas-relief carvings, and plaques mounted beneath them tell the story of a forgotten Waterdavian family.
{@b Statues}. Two 9-foot-tall statues stand on raised platforms in alcoves to the north and south.

The bas-reliefs carvings depict Arandraya, Maelweene, and Yarlithra Shadowdusk negotiating trade deals in Waterdeep, exploring Undermountain in their free time, pouring treasure into family coffers, and giving a black tablet to their brother, Xerrion. The carvings go on to show the original Shadowdusk Hold (in Waterdeep) on fire, Xerrion Shadowdusk escaping into Undermountain with the black tablet, the creation of a new Shadowdusk Hold in the dungeon's depths, Xerrion's marriage to Lady Margaraste, and the married couple stepping through a gate of tentacles into the Far Realm.

A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check identifies the family crest in the reliefs—a lit torch with an orange flame and three embers trailing off it—and the two mottoes of House Shadowdusk: "No secrets without truth" and "We do not fear the darkness." The crest appears upright in earlier scenes and inverted in later scenes. A character who recognizes the crest and the family mottoes also knows that the Shadowdusks were presumed destroyed.

The statue to the north depicts Lord Xerrion Shadowdusk, a male human of middle age with regal bearing and sharp features. The south statue depicts Lady Margaraste Shadowdusk, a middle-aged female human with long, curly hair and a kind smile. An inscription on the bottom of each statue identifies its subject.

entries.name: 3. West Wing
entries: Four {@creature Nothic||nothics} lurk in the northern arm of this L-shaped gallery, poring over wall carvings and chattering to themselves. Beyond the nothics, a staircase descends 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}.
The nothics are puzzled by the carvings, which depict various deceased members of the Shadowdusk family. They attack intruders on sight.

entries.name: 4. Decayed Quarters
entries: This suite of chambers has been destroyed by the creatures now in residence here, all traces of the rooms' previous purposes obliterated.

entries.name: 4a. Grell Nest
entries: A hive-like nest with multiple dark openings fills the southern half of this room. Seven {@creature Grell||grells} lurk inside the wet, papery nest and emerge from it to attack intruders.

entries.name: 4b. Mad Creature

entries: {@b Nothic}. A {@creature nothic} squats near the east wall, frantically scratching at the stone.
{@b Scrawls}. Scrawled exhortations in Deep Speech and Undercommon cover the walls, floor, and ceiling.

The nothic used to be an apprentice mage named Rhamagant, who served as {@creature Vertrand Shadowdusk|WDMM}'s assistant (see {@area area 17|ac1|x} for more information about Vertrand). The nothic remembers nothing of its previous life and fights only in self-defense. A character who questions the nothic in a language it understands can glean the following useful information amid its mad ravings:

items: This level of Undermountain is called Shadowdusk Hold, and it has three tiers.
The deeper into Shadowdusk Hold one goes, the closer one gets to the Far Realm.
There's a secret room on each tier.

entries: The nothic knows the locations of all the secret doors leading to the secret rooms in Shadowdusk Hold (areas {@area 11|aaa}, {@area 23b|ad7}, and {@area 37|afe}). Any character who can communicate with the nothic can, with a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion}) check, convince it to accompany the party and point out secret doors. When it comes within 10 feet of a secret door in Shadowdusk Hold, the nothic begins scratching at it while muttering the words "secret door" in Undercommon.
{@b Cold}. This chamber is kept magically cold.
{@b Shelves}. Shelves line every wall, all of them stacked with wine, ale, and perishable food.
{@b Casks}. Several wooden casks of drinkable water stand along one wall.
{@b Furnishings}. This room contains an iron stove, three wooden tables for preparing food, and a cupboard holding silver utensils and dishware.
{@b Unseen Servants}. Four {@creature Living Unseen Servant|WDMM|living unseen servants} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) prepare meals on command and use brooms to sweep the floor.

entries.name: 7. Derelict Shrine
entries: An incomplete statue partially hewn from marble stands in the middle of the area. The stone is carved into the rough shape of the god Torm. Someone who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check identifies the statue's unfinished features as the iconography of the god of duty, loyalty, and law.

entries.name: 8. Nothic's Niche

entries: {@b Fissure}. A {@creature nothic} hides in a 5-foot-wide natural fissure in the 20-foot-high ceiling.
{@b Furnishings}. A rectangular stone table with ten chairs stands at the center of the room. The table and the floor around it are strewn with debris from the crumbling ceiling.
{@b Tapestry}. A great tapestry covers the west wall. It depicts a noble wedding inside a vast chamber that has shadowy tentacles sprouting from its dark corners.

The nothic uses the fissure in the ceiling as a private lair. It observes intruders and uses its Weird {@skill Insight} on interesting-looking characters so it can later report any secrets it learns to {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|WDMM}. It leaves the niche only if attacked and fights to the death to defend its lair.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed on a shelf inside the nothic's ceiling niche are 15 pp and 200 gp in a leather sack, and a {@item potion of supreme healing} in a glass vial fastened to a silver necklace (25 gp).
The tapestry depicts the ghastly wedding of Xerrion and Margaraste Shadowdusk. It is worth 750 gp and weighs 50 pounds.

entries.name: 9. East Wing

entries: {@b Drifting Light}. A visible {@creature will-o'-wisp} drifts through this long, L-shaped gallery.
{@b Carving}. An alcove in the corner of the L bears a relief carving of Shadowdusk nobles being paid respect by the common folk.
{@b Stairs}. A staircase at the end of the north arm of the gallery descends 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}.

The will-o'-wisp serves Melissara in {@area area 10a|aa4|x}. It wanders from one end of the hall to the other, waiting for her summons, but turns {@condition invisible} and flees to warn her at the first sign of intruders.

entries.name: 10. Noble Quarters
entries: This suite belongs to {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM}, a distant cousin of the Shadowdusk twins, and her deranged husband, Derrion.

entries.name: 10a. Melissara's Chamber

entries: {@b Melissara}. A middle-aged woman ({@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM}) sits in an easy chair in the northeast corner, reading and muttering to herself.
{@b Other Furnishings}. A canopied bed and an armoire stand against the south wall, and a silk curtain obscures a corridor to the north.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the east wall opens into Melissara's study ({@area area 11|aaa|x}).

Melissara has so far managed to escape the horrible insanity that besets the rest of her family, but she can sense that her mind is slowly being eroded by contact with the Far Realm. Fearing that her descent into madness is inevitable, she lives in a state of self-imposed exile and chooses to remain in Shadowdusk Hold despite every instinct telling her to flee.
Melissara is a human {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Melissara is neutral.
She speaks Common, Deep Speech, Draconic, and Dwarvish.
She has the {@spell dimension door} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.

entries: If the characters address her in a civilized manner, Melissara listens to what they have to say. She then implores them to destroy Dezmyr and Zalthar before they can enact their plan to conquer Waterdeep, not realizing that death knights are not so easily vanquished. Melissara asks that she and Derrion be left out of the ensuing conflict and provides the following information to the characters in good faith:

items: All members of the Shadowdusk family have, to some extent, been corrupted by the Far Realm. To the best of Melissara's knowledge, the damage is irreparable.
Other family members living in Shadowdusk Hold include Melissara's three cousins: the wizards Berlain, Cassiok, and Vertrand.

Dezmyr and Zalthar are death knights that dwell on the lower tiers of Shadowdusk Hold. Contact with the Far Realm has given Dezmyr the ability to warp reality to a limited extent. Zalthar has no such ability but wields a sword that drains souls.

The lowest tier of Shadowdusk Hold is home to a blue dracolich in league with the death knights. (Melissara knows the dracolich's phylactery is hidden somewhere in Shadowdusk Hold, but doesn't know where.)

entries: If the characters have no interest in conversing with Melissara, she uses {@spell dimension door} to get to {@area area 11|aaa|x} and sends her lunatic husband to eliminate them.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The armoire holds fine clothing and a wooden jewelry box containing a pair of matching gold bracelets (250 gp each), a gold-and-pearl necklace (1,250 gp), and the key to the strongbox in {@area area 10b|aa7|x}.

entries.name: 10b. Derrion's Chamber

entries: {@b Derrion}. A middle-aged man with a scarred face (Derrion Shadowdusk) is pacing about the room anxiously.
{@b Furnishings}. These include a simple bed to the west, a dresser filled with clothes to the east, and a weapon and armor rack.
Derrion enjoys killing unwelcome visitors. He is a human {@creature champion|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), with these changes:

items: Derrion is chaotic evil.
He speaks Common and Deep Speech.
Derrion stores his weapons and plate armor on the equipment racks. If he doesn't have time to don his plate armor, he makes do with a chain shirt (AC 15).

entries: Derrion accompanies Melissara whenever she leaves their suite, fearing that she will come to harm without his protection. He lives in constant fear that adventurers might invade Shadowdusk Hold and lay waste to it. Prolonged exposure to the Far Realm has made him sleep-deprived and irritable. His eyes are bloodshot, and he hears whispers of things that aren't real. Only Melissara can control his inexplicable rage toward visitors.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Under the bed is a locked strongbox containing 200 pp and 1,000 gp. The key in area {@area 10a|aa4} unlocks the strongbox, which can also be opened with a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic, or by a character using thieves' tools who succeeds on a DC 15 Dexterity check.
{@b Bookcase}. A long bookcase with glass doors takes up much of the north wall (see "Bookcase" below).
{@b Desk}. A sturdy writing desk covered in stacks of parchment stands against the east wall (see "Desk" below).
{@b Workbench}. A workbench near the south wall holds a set of alchemist's supplies.

entries.name: Bookcase
entries: The bookcase's glass doors aren't locked.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The case holds texts on various arcane subjects, focusing on evocation magic and planar travel. Three of the texts are valuable (100 gp each). They are titled {@i Tenebrous and the True Path to Lichdom}, {@i Musings of a Planar Traveler}, and {@i Touched by the Far Realm: A Wizard's Lamentable Descent into Lunacy}. Tucked among these mundane tomes is Melissara's spellbook, which bears the (right side up) Shadowdusk family crest on the cover and contains the spells Melissara has prepared, plus {@spell arcane lock} and {@spell glyph of warding}.

entries.name: Desk
entries: The desk holds an orderly stack of notes. Half of the notes detail meticulous magical experiments and studies regarding the nature of the Far Realm. The other notes are nonsensical ravings that hint at a fractured mind slowly coming undone.

The bottom drawer is sealed with an {@spell arcane lock} spell cast by Melissara. Inside is a small black journal. The first page of the book is trapped with a {@spell glyph of warding} spell, whose explosive runes deal fire damage (save DC 15). The glyph is keyed to go off if anyone but Melissara opens the journal (a precaution to prevent her cousins from reading it and discovering her secrets).

The journal details Melissara's unease with her family, as well as her growing fear of losing her mind and soul to the Far Realm. She seems desperate to use her writings in the journal as a touchstone to her own mind.
{@b Tapestry}. A beautiful tapestry covers the west wall (see "Treasure" below).
{@b Furnishings}. Several sitting areas with comfortable chairs and side tables are arranged about the room. An empty bottle of fine wine stands on an end table next to a used wineglass.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the north wall opens into Melissara's study ({@area area 11|aaa|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tapestry depicts the original Shadowdusk Hold, an impressive villa overgrown with ivy that stood in Waterdeep's Sea Ward until it was burned to the ground. The tapestry is worth 250 gp and weighs 50 pounds.

entries.name: 13. Walking Dead

entries: {@b Zombie}. A human {@creature zombie} in rotting, soiled robes shuffles back and forth through the room. A powerful stench of decay accompanies it.
{@b Furnishings}. Moldy furnishings include a bed, a desk strewn with yellowed papers, and a barren bookshelf.

The zombie is what remains of Zail Ephram, a human wizard and adventurer who was killed in Shadowdusk Hold. {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM} ({@area see area 10a|aa4|x}) used an {@spell animate dead} spell to animate the wizard's corpse. The zombie has nothing of value and attacks any creature that disturbs it other than its creator.

The papers on the desk are architectural drawings. Characters who spend 1 hour studying the drawings can piece together accurate maps of tiers 1 and 2 of Shadowdusk Hold, except for secret doors and areas hidden behind them.

entries.name: 14. Training Room

entries: {@b Mannequins}. Two wooden practice dummies stand near the east and west walls.
{@b Racks}. A weapon rack and an armor rack hang on the north wall, one to each side of the doorway.
{@b Mats}. Canvas mats stuffed with straw are spread out to create a sparring area in the middle of the room.

The armor rack contains two shields and two suits each of leather, studded leather, chain shirt, and plate armor. The weapon rack contains one matched pair each of longswords, daggers, battleaxes, quarterstaffs, warhammers, and spears.

entries.name: 15. Fountain
entries: A low-walled marble fountain with a statue of an aboleth as its centerpiece dominates the room. Water spills from the aboleth's mouth and splashes noisily into the stone basin. Drain holes in the basin's rim prevent overflow.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell cast on the fountain reveals an aura of conjuration around the aboleth statue, contained within which is the source of the water: a {@item decanter of endless water}. The decanter can be obtained only by destroying the statue, which has AC 17, 60 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Tier 2
entries: Stairs from {@area areas 3|a94|x} and {@area 9|aa1} lead down 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}. Vertrand and Berlain, two thoroughly corrupt and evil members of the Shadowdusk family, inhabit this tier.
Barely perceptible whispers can be heard throughout the tier, and shadowy forms constantly writhe and recoil at the corner of each character's eye.

entries.name: 16. Arcane Sanctum
entries: Three {@condition invisible} {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} linger in this area in case Vertrand or Berlain require their services.

entries.name: 16a. Burned Library
entries: Berlain (see {@area area 18b|ac9|x}) lost her temper here a tenday ago and used multiple {@spell fireball} spells to destroy the room's contents.
{@b Burned Shelves and Racks}. The walls are lined with burned bookshelves and scroll racks.
{@b Charred Furnishings}. The charred remains of three padded chairs and three coffee tables lie atop badly burned rugs in the middle of the floor.

entries.name: 16b. Laboratory
entries: A workbench along the west wall of this area is covered with tools, components, and magical apparatus.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The bench holds a set of {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, a {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}, a {@item healer's kit|PHB}, and an unlit lantern filled with oil. A recently brewed {@item potion of invisibility} rests among other vials that contain mundane liquids.

entries.name: 16c. Clean Room

entries: {@b Antimagic}. All magic is suppressed here, as if by an {@spell antimagic field} spell.
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry on the south wall depicts a landscape of trees made of tentacles, and floating islands of rock covered with drooling mouths and bloodshot eyeballs (see "Treasure" below).

This room is used to rid objects and creatures of undesirable magical energy that might destabilize a sensitive experiment. In addition to the antimagic effect always active in the room, any creature that passes through this area has any magic items it carries and any magical effects active on it suppressed for {@dice 1d4} minutes after it exits. {@spell Detect magic} cast from outside the room does not detect the antimagic field.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tapestry weighs 30 pounds and is worth 250 gp (assuming the characters can find a buyer who appreciates its disturbing, otherworldly imagery).

entries.name: 17. Vertrand's Room

entries: {@b Vertrand}. A bald, elderly man ({@creature Vertrand Shadowdusk|WDMM}) sits at a writing desk to the north, his back to the doorway.
{@b Bed}. A simple bed stands against the south wall.

{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry hanging on the east wall depicts noble members of the Shadowdusk family, their features distorted in unnatural and frightening ways. (Close examination reveals that the tapestry has been damaged by mold, rendering it worthless.)

Vertrand has smooth flesh where his eyes should be, for he surrendered his ocular orbits to a Far Realm entity in exchange for {@sense blindsight}. Having foreseen the arrival of intruders, Vertrand has elected to face them alone. "Death owns us all," he says, before rising to his feet and unleashing his destructive spells.
Vertrand is a human {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Vertrand is chaotic evil and speaks Abyssal, Common, Deep Speech, and Undercommon.
He has {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 60 feet, but is blind beyond this radius.
Han har förberett {@spell confusion} trollformeln istället för {@spell banishment}.

entries: Vertrand's desk holds writing implements and handwritten notes written by Vertrand before he lost his eyes. The notes are difficult to follow and require a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to decipher. The notes detail Vertrand's research into magical vortices, and how to widen and destabilize planar portals.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Vertrand's spellbook is in the desk's top drawer. It contains all the spells he has prepared, plus {@spell legend lore}, {@spell conjure elemental}, and {@spell planar binding}. The spells are written out using a form of Braille script.

entries.name: 18. Berlain's Suite
entries: A horribly disfigured mage named {@creature Berlain Shadowdusk|WDMM} claims these chambers.

entries.name: 18a. Study

entries: {@b Furnishings}. A black stone desk stands to the south. Next to the desk is a slender stone lectern with an open book resting on it.
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry covering the east wall shows a tentacled creature from nightmare stuffing a number of naked, terrified humanoids into its black maw.

Berlain's notes, strewn across her desk, are a blend of arcane esoterica and insane pronouncements. All of it paints a picture of horrific experiments performed on living humanoids. A recently scrawled annotation laments a lack of fresh subjects that is stalling her work.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Berlain's spellbook rests atop the lectern. It contains all the spells she has prepared, plus {@spell fireball} and {@spell modify memory}.
The tapestry weighs 40 pounds and is worth 250 gp (assuming the characters can find a buyer who appreciates its disturbing imagery).

entries.name: 18b. Bedchamber

entries: {@b Furnishings}. A chest of drawers and a bed heaped with pillows stand along the west wall. A sitting area with comfortable chairs is set up against the east wall.
{@b Monsters}. A mutated humanoid ({@creature Berlain Shadowdusk|WDMM}) sits on the edge of the bed, patching gashes in her robe. Floating nearby are two {@creature Grell||grells}.

A little over a year ago, Berlain and her brother Korva briefly entered the Far Realm, whereupon they became fused into a single physical form. This merging obliterated most of Korva's body and personality, leaving Berlain with an extra mouth and an extra set of arms that once belonged to her brother. She also inherited a few of his internal organs and personality traits. She can speak using one or both of her mouths.

Berlain has dirty blonde hair, piercing dark eyes, and two mouths where one would normally be—one below the other, canted at an angle. Sprouting from her misshapen shoulders are two pairs of arms—her original limbs above those of her brother. She wears a poorly stitched robe made from other garments and designed to fit her mutated form.

Berlain has a close kinship with Vertrand, and the two wizards work well together. Berlain has no interest in forging alliances with visitors and tries to capture intruders for use as experimental subjects.
Berlain is an {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Berlain is a chaotic evil aberration who speaks Common, Deep Speech, Grell, and Undercommon.
She has the {@spell polymorph} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.
As a bonus action, she can use her extra mouth and arms to cast any cantrip she has prepared.

entries: The grells serve as Berlain's valets, and she communicates with them in their own language. The grells try to grapple and subdue intruders on sight.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest of drawers contains torn-up scraps of clothing. In the bottom drawer is an unlocked coffer containing 300 gp, a polished crystal orb carved to look like a glistening doppelganger eyeball (usable as an arcane focus), and a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell flesh to stone}.

entries.name: 19. Shadowdusk Hold Fresco
entries: This chamber is empty except for a dusty fresco on the north wall. Measuring 30 feet long by 15 feet tall, it depicts a stately, ivy-covered mansion and estate that once stood in Waterdeep—the original Shadowdusk Hold.

Situated in small niches that form the mansion's windows are tiny, 3-inch-tall painted wooden busts representing members of the Shadowdusk household circa 1355 DR. Characters who have seen other depictions of Arandraya, Maelweene, Yarlithra, and Xerrion Shadowdusk recognize their tiny likenesses alongside the busts of other family members and servants. Two window niches are noticeably empty, because Zalthar has removed the busts within ({@area see area 34a|af5|x}).

entries.name: 20. Pillared Hall
entries: Stone pillars support the flat, 40-foot-high ceiling. Every sound here is amplified, such that even a whispered voice or soft footstep can be heard throughout areas 20a, 20b, and 20c. Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks to move silently through the area are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: 20a. Central Chamber

entries: {@b Guards}. Five {@condition invisible} {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} patrol this area.
{@b Dais}. Five steps lead to the top of a stone dais, at the back of which is a set of gold-plated double doors that open into {@area area 22|ad3|x}.

If visitors arrive unannounced, the {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} become visible and impatiently question the new arrivals. Characters must present a plausible reason for their presence and succeed on a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Deception} or {@skill Persuasion}) check to convince the {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} not to attack them. If they don't like what they hear, three of the wisps attack. The other two break away to warn Vertrand ({@area area 17|ac1|x}) and Berlain ({@area area 18b|ac9|x}), who, along with Berlain's grell valets, converge on this area. If a battle erupts here, the nothics in {@area area 20b|ad0|x} join the fray.

entries.name: 20b. West Atrium
entries: Five {@creature Nothic||nothics} hide behind the pillars in this area. They fight alongside the {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} in {@area area 20a|ace|x} but avoid combat otherwise. If the characters attack the nothics, any {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} in {@area area 20a|ace|x} come to the nothics' aid.

entries.name: 20c. East Atrium
entries: This side chamber is unoccupied.

entries.name: 21. Parlor
entries: Simple yet comfortable furniture is set around this dusty parlor, which has not seen much use in recent years. A sideboard standing against the northwest wall has a large, steel-framed mirror mounted above it.
{@b Altar and Fresco}. Three steps ascend to an alcove holding a stone altar. The wall behind the altar bears a fresco of a large white gauntlet (the symbol of Torm).

{@b Statues}. Standing in the "tips" of the crescent-shaped room, flanking the altar, are a pair of life-size stone statues that depict human paladins clad in plate armor. (The statues resemble {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|wdmm|Dezmyr} and {@creature Zalthar Shadowdusk|wdmm} as they appeared when they were alive.)

entries.name: 23. Meditation Rooms
entries: Shadowdusk family members use these rooms for silent reflection and contemplation.

entries.name: 23a. Outer Sanctum
entries: Soft cushions and woven mats adorn the floor of this fragrant room. Brass censers hold cones of unlit incense. A secret door in the southeast wall leads to {@area area 23b|ad7|x}.

entries.name: 23b. Black Crystal Tablet
entries: This chamber contains no light sources and is unnaturally dark. Any bright light that shines into this room or inside it is reduced to dim light, and dim light is reduced to darkness. {@sense Darkvision} functions normally here.

A stone table rests against the wall opposite the door. A tablet made of black crystal inscribed with strange writing rests on the table. The tablet is cold to the touch, and its writing appears to writhe.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Xerrion Shadowdusk originally used the tablet to contact beings of the Far Realm. Other family members have used it for similar purposes over the years. It weighs 11 pounds and measures 7 inches wide, 13 inches tall, and 2 inches thick.

The {@item black crystal tablet|WDMM} is a legendary magic item that requires attunement by a creature that has proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill. Any creature that attunes to the tablet must make a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw at the end of its next long rest. On a failed save, the creature becomes afflicted with a random form of long-term madness (see "{@book Madness|DMG|8|Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

As an action, a creature attuned to the {@item black crystal tablet|WDMM} can use it to cast {@spell eyebite} or {@spell gate} (the portal created by this spell links to the Far Realm only). After the tablet is used to cast a spell, it cannot be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: 24. Nothic Warrens
entries: This wing of Shadowdusk Hold serves as the home of family members whose mad thirst for arcane knowledge transformed them into {@creature Nothic||nothics}.

entries.name: 24a. Communal Area
entries: Twelve {@creature Nothic||nothics} gather here and glare suspiciously at strangers while spouting nonsense among themselves. If the characters do anything to startle the nothics, they attack; otherwise, the nothics let characters pass through this room unmolested.

entries.name: 24b. Peek-a-Boo
entries: Two {@creature Nothic||nothics} cower beneath mounds of rotting tapestries piled against the east wall. The nothics sheepishly observe passersby and avoid combat.

entries.name: 24c. Rotting Refuse
entries: The {@creature Nothic||nothics} throw garbage here, including the half-eaten corpses of rats, bats, and other vermin. The shredded remains of a tapestry depicting the city of Waterdeep hang on the south wall.

entries.name: 25. Abandoned Chamber
entries: This room served as quarters for members of the Shadowdusk family until they became nothics. Nothing remains except for splintered furniture and a shredded, unidentifiable tapestry hanging on the west wall.

entries.name: 26. Hoarded Secrets
entries: The {@creature Nothic||nothics} steal books and store them in this chamber, the features of which are as follows:
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry depicting silhouetted figures standing before a starry sky covers the west wall.
{@b Towers of Books}. Stacks of books are set around the room, some rising almost to the ceiling.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A search of the stacks turns up four profoundly philosophical texts worth 250 gp each to an interested sage. Their titles are {@i Patterns in the Tapestry of Time}, {@i The U'keth Prophecies}, {@i Whispers of a Bygone Truth}, and {@i Tales of Existential Dread}.
The tapestry features a stunning night sky set with pearls and diamond chips as stars, but the constellations match none known in Faerûn. The tapestry is worth 2,500 gp and weighs 30 pounds.

entries.name: 27. Privy
entries: This room contains several filthy latrine stalls and is caked in waste. The Shadowdusks use chamber pots that the nothics empty into this area. The nothics use the privy with no regard for its condition.

entries.name: 28. Legacy of Xerrion
entries: Two sets of double doors lead to this hall, and opening either set alerts the creatures on guard here. The hall's contents are as follows:

{@b Slaadi}. Four {@condition invisible} {@creature Death Slaad||death slaadi} stand guard next to the northernmost pillars. The slaadi serve at the pleasure of Dezmyr and Zalthar, and they attack intruders on sight.

{@b Fresco}. Two stone benches arranged side by side in the middle of the hall face a colorful fresco on the north wall. The fresco, 30 feet long by 15 feet tall, depicts a slender, middle-aged human wizard (Xerrion Shadowdusk) standing before a magic portal with tentacles pouring out of it. The wizard is smiling, and clutched in his arms is a black crystal tablet.
{@b Statue}. To the north is a 10-foot-tall statue of a grimacing man being crushed to death by stony tentacles erupting from the floor.
{@b Stairs}. To the south, a spiral staircase descends 50 feet to {@area area 30a|ae9|x}.

entries.name: Tier 3
entries: The unnatural corruption of the Far Realm pervades the deepest level of Shadowdusk Hold. Any creature other than a denizen of the hold that finishes a long rest in this tier must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature gains no benefit from the rest and is afflicted with a random form of long-term madness (see "{@book Madness|DMG|8|Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: 30. Lower Halls
entries: The staircase from {@area tier 2|a92|x} ends before these halls, which look older than the rest of Shadowdusk Hold.

entries.name: 30a. Shadowdusk Hall

entries: {@b House Crest}. Set into the middle of the floor is a 20-foot-diameter disk of purple stone, inscribed upon which is the Shadowdusk crest: a lit torch with three trailing embers, its orange flame pointed toward the double door to the west.
{@b Mosaics}. The 40-foot-high, vaulted ceiling bears peeling mosaics of cloudy, dramatically lit skies.
{@b Scorch Marks}. The walls and pillars have numerous scorch marks.
{@b Statues}. Four 8-foot-tall statues of human nobles stand in wide alcoves to the north and south.

A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check can ascertain that the scorch marks on the walls and pillars were made by a blue dragon's breath weapon. Years ago, Halaster lured a dracolich named Lynnorax to Shadowdusk Hold. Dezmyr and Zalthar pressed the dracolich into service. The dracolich waits for intruders in {@area area 40|b0e|x} and guards the death knights' vault ({@area area 41|b10|x}).

The statues in the northern alcoves depict Arandraya and Maelweene Shadowdusk. The statues to the south depict their brother, Xerrion, and their other sister, Yarlithra. Each statue stands atop a 2-foot-high block of stone that bears an inscription of the noble's name.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A locked secret door is hidden in the wall next to the statue of Xerrion in the southwest alcove. A character who examines the statue and succeeds on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices that one of the rings on Xerrion's left hand can be twisted around his finger. Turning the ring unlocks the secret door and causes it to swing open into {@area area 37|afe|x}.

entries.name: 30b. Family Crypts
entries: This arched, 15-foot-high hall is lined with alcoves. Each alcove contains a dusty stone casket holding the remains of a dead Shadowdusk family member, but no treasure.

entries.name: 31. Approach to Madness
entries: The Far Realm has twisted these rooms, causing the lines where floor, walls, ceiling, and pillars meet to appear warped.

entries.name: 31a. Warped Foyer
entries: This chamber is lined with twisted columns that seem to change shape slightly every few minutes.
{@b Far Realm Proximity}. A strange energy can be felt emanating from the double door to the west. The closer a creature comes to the doors, the more uneasy it feels.

{@b Slaadi}. Four {@condition invisible} {@creature Death Slaad||death slaadi} stand in front of the double door leading to {@area area 32|af2|x}. The slaadi serve at the pleasure of Dezmyr and Zalthar, and they attack intruders on sight.
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry on the east wall depicts a group of humans twisting, warping, and melting into one amorphous, blasphemous entity.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tapestry weighs 50 pounds and is worth 750 gp to one who appreciates such horrid decor.

entries.name: 32. Far and Gone
entries: The curving west wall of this room is a seething mass of color and sickly light—a partially breached portal to the Far Realm. Creatures can't physically pass through the portal, but the Far Realm's influence bleeds out into the Material Plane from this place. A character can ascertain the true nature of the portal with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check.

Any creature that comes into contact with the back wall must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by the wall for 1 minute. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the creature is {@condition stunned} and stares at the wall, absorbing the power and madness of the Far Realm. The effect ends if the creature takes damage, or if another creature uses an action to shake or slap it. When the effect ends, the creature that was {@condition charmed} gains a random form of indefinite madness (see "{@book Madness|DMG|8|Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: 33. Shrine
entries: Zalthar maintains this area as a shrine to his sister Dezmyr. Her painted likenesses—both as she was in life and as a death knight—hang in frames on every wall.

entries.name: 34. Zalthar's Chambers
entries: Zalthar languishes in these chambers, shunning all other creatures except his sister.

entries.name: 34a. Zalthar Shadowdusk

entries: {@b Furnishings}. This room is furnished with several chairs and sofas, all covered in dust and cobwebs.

{@b Easel}. A wooden easel stands in the northeast corner, draped in a black cloth. (Under the cloth, resting on the easel, is a half-finished portrait of Dezmyr as she was in life, lying nude on a bed of tentacles.)

{@b Zalthar}. Seated in a chair, facing the northern and western doors, is {@creature Zalthar Shadowdusk|wdmm}—a death knight in black armor. In his withered hands, he holds two tiny painted wooden figurines (busts of himself and his sister as young children, which he took from the fresco in {@area area 19|acc|x}).
The adventurers catch Zalthar in a moment of reflection, and he considers their presence an affront. He is a {@creature death knight}, with these changes:

items: Zalthar wields a {@item nine lives stealer} longsword with 5 charges remaining. He has a +13 bonus to hit with the weapon. On a hit, he deals 11 ({@dice 1d8 + 7}) slashing damage, or 12 ({@dice 1d10 + 7}) slashing damage if used with two hands, plus 18 ({@dice 4d8}) necrotic damage.
He has the {@spell locate creature} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.
He speaks Abyssal, Common, and Deep Speech.

entries: When intruders enter the room, Zalthar stands, draws his sword, and says, "Dezmyr foretold your arrival. I've been waiting for you." He then tries to destroy them.

entries.name: 34b. Black Obelisk
entries: This 20-foot-high room contains a single object: a 15-foot-tall, tapered obelisk of black stone situated in the middle of the room.

The Shadowdusks found the obelisk on another level of Undermountain and brought it here after subjecting it to Far Realm energies. It radiates a strong aura of abjuration magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell or similar magic, and a paladin using Divine Sense can detect a celestial presence trapped within it.

Characters who have a combined Strength of 60 or higher can topple the obelisk, which is a Huge object with AC 17, 90 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Toppling or destroying the obelisk releases a {@creature couatl} trapped within. The couatl, named Tezca-Zyanya, appears in the form of a Tiny yellow frog. Using its telepathy, the disguised couatl thanks the characters for releasing it. Exposure to the Far Realm has deprived the couatl of its memories, including those that would explain its entrapment and the purpose of the obelisk.

If the party includes no evil characters, Tezca-Zyanya offers to accompany its rescuers and assist them until its services are no longer required. It continues to pass itself off as a frog until circumstances force it to reveal its true form. Trapped in the obelisk for millennia, it knows nothing about Undermountain or Waterdeep.

entries.name: 35. Eyes of Stone
entries: This chamber is the only means by which characters can enter {@adventure level 23|WDMM|23} of Undermountain.

{@b Arch}. A stone arch is embedded in the east wall between the two arms of the chamber. The arch's keystone is carved with the visage of Halaster, whose eyes follow any creature that approaches the arch.
{@b Petrified Beholder}. In the northern arm of the room, a {@condition petrified} beholder sprawls on its side on the floor.

The beholder has been here longer than the Shadowdusks. If released from its {@condition petrified} state with a {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic, it attacks other creatures indiscriminately.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 23
entries: Bågen är en av Halasters portar (se "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Reglerna för den är följande:

items: If any creature touches the arch, the face shouts out in Common: "Yield magic for safe passage!" A stone arm with a flat, outstretched hand then rises from the floor before the arch. If a magic item of at least uncommon rarity is placed into the hand, it sinks back into the floor with the item, which is teleported to Halaster's study in area 37 of level 23. The gate then opens for 1 minute. If an appropriate magic item is not placed in the hand within 10 seconds of its appearance, it points to the nearest creature that Halaster's visage can see. That creature must succeed on a DC 22 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition petrified}.

Characters must be 17th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 1 on level 23|b1a|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the similar gate located there.

entries.name: 36. Vacant Rooms
entries: The Shadowdusks never visit these rooms. Characters who rest here are unlikely to be disturbed.

entries.name: 36a. Empty Chamber
entries: This room stands empty.

entries.name: 36b. Rubble-Strewn Room
entries: Rubble is scattered across the floor beneath a 20-foot-long, 5-foot-wide gash where part of the ceiling has collapsed.

entries.name: 37. Secret Room
entries: This unlit chamber connects areas {@area 30a|ae9} and {@area 38c|b06} by way of secret doors. The secret doors are readily identifiable and easily opened from inside the room.

entries.name: Xunderbrok
entries: If the word "xunderbrok" is spoken aloud anywhere in this room, a granite cone magically appears on the floor in the southernmost corner of the room. (See {@area level 6, area 39c|3a6|x}, for the significance of this word.) The cone is 4 feet tall and 2 feet wide at the base. Close examination reveals that the top of the cone unscrews to reveal a hollow compartment under the cap.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The cone's compartment contains a {@item potion of giant strength} (cloud) in a stoppered, J-shaped crystal flask worth 25 gp.

entries.name: 38. Dezmyr's Chambers
entries: Dezmyr dwells here, plotting the conquest of Waterdeep and the destruction of her family's ancient enemies.

entries.name: 38a. Memento Mori

entries: {@b Tapestry}. A large tapestry depicting the city of Waterdeep hangs on the east wall.
{@b Skull}. A charred human skull rests atop a 3-foot-high stone pedestal in front of the tapestry.

The charred skull is all that remains of Dezmyr's mother, Yarlithra Shadowdusk, who perished in the blaze that destroyed the original Shadowdusk Hold in Waterdeep. Dezmyr keeps her mother's skull as a memento to remind her of her ambitions and purpose.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Examination of the tapestry reveals that all the flags flapping above the city bear the upright Shadowdusk family crest. The tapestry is worth 250 gp and weighs 50 pounds.

entries.name: 38b. Storage
entries: This room contains unused furniture draped in cobwebs, including a canopied bed and a claw-footed armoire. A headless wooden mannequin in the southwest corner wears a dusty yellow ball gown more than a century out of fashion.

entries.name: 38c. Dezmyr's Sanctum

entries: {@b Dezmyr}. {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|wdmm} (see below) stands in the middle of the room, clad in ancient armor and joined by six {@creature Wraith||wraiths} (her counselors).

{@b Portraits}. Dozens of framed portraits hang from hooks on the south and west walls. (The portraits represent various members of the Shadowdusk family. All the depictions are warped in subtle ways. Some of the family members have starry eyes, while others have melted flesh or tentacles sprouting from their faces.)

{@b Fresco}. A 10-foot-square, tiled fresco on the middle of the east wall depicts {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|wdmm|Dezmyr} and {@creature Zalthar Shadowdusk|wdmm} as heavily armored human paladins of Torm, riding on armored horses and brandishing shields. Zalthar's shield is mostly hidden behind his body and horse, but displayed prominently on Dezmyr's shield is the Shadowdusk family crest (a lit, upright torch with three embers trailing off it, set against a purple disk).

Dezmyr is so touched by the Far Realm that she speaks in riddles. As soon as one or more characters enter the room, she says, "The stars turn, and a time presents itself." She then draws her sword and attacks, aided by the wraiths. Dezmyr is a {@creature death knight}, with these changes:

items: As a bonus action on her turn, Dezmyr can warp reality, undoing damage dealt to herself or another creature that she can see within 20 feet of her. The beneficiary of this warped reality instantly regains 10 hit points.
She has the {@spell locate creature} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.
She speaks Abyssal, Common, and Deep Speech.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Set into the east wall, north of the fresco of Dezmyr on horseback, is a locked secret door. Any character who studies the fresco and succeeds on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check can tell that the family crest on Dezmyr's shield can be rotated. Turning it so that the torch is upside down instead of upright unlocks the secret door and causes it to swing open into {@area area 37|afe|x}.

entries.name: 39. Dracolich's Phylactery
entries: The Far Realm has warped the fabric of this chamber and its current occupant. The contents of this 20-foot-high room are as follows:
{@b Undulations}. The walls and pillars undulate and bulge, as though the stone were amorphous. (The effect is unnerving but harmless.)
{@b Statue}. A deep alcove in the north wall contains a life-size statue whose human features seems to change every few seconds (see "{@area Morphing Statue|b0b|x}" below).

{@b Cassiok and Pet}. Facing the statue with its back to the rest of the room is a black-robed creature ({@creature Cassiok Shadowdusk|WDMM}) leaning heavily on a staff. Next to Cassiok is his loyal pet, a {@creature grick alpha}, and an {@condition invisible} {@creature gray slaad} that serves as his valet.

{@creature Cassiok Shadowdusk|WDMM} is a middle-aged man transformed by prolonged exposure to the Far Realm. Although his head remains human, his body is that of a giant beetle that walks on its hind legs.
Cassiok is an {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: He is a chaotic evil aberration who speaks Common, Deep Speech, Infernal, and Undercommon.
He has the {@spell phantasmal killer} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.
He wears the gray slaad's control gem (a fist-sized gray gem) on a chain around his neck.
He wields a {@item staff of power} that grants him a +2 bonus to Armor Class, spell attack rolls, and saving throws. His insectoid physiology prevents him from making melee attacks with the staff.

entries: Cassiok is insane and attacks anyone who isn't a member of his family. The grick and the gray slaad defend him. If reduced to 20 hit points or fewer, Cassiok uses his next action to break his {@item staff of power} in a retributive strike, cursing the characters as he does so.

entries.name: Morphing Statue
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell cast on the statue reveals an aura of transmutation magic surrounding it and a powerful source of necromancy magic deep inside it.

Without significantly changing its mass, the statue shifts form every few seconds, becoming various members of the Shadowdusk family and, every so often, depicting {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM} or other humanoid creatures that have come into contact with it over the years. When a humanoid creature touches the statue, it temporarily morphs into that creature before assuming one of its other forms. Regardless of the form the statue takes, its features are slightly deformed, as though carved by an inept sculptor.

entries.name: Phylactery
entries: Embedded in the heart of the statue is a black sapphire the size of an apple. This gemstone is worth 5,000 gp and serves as the phylactery of Lynnorax the dracolich (see area 40). If the dracolich is slain, its life force becomes trapped in the jewel until it can possess another dragon corpse and rise again. The gem is destroyed if subjected to the fiery breath of an ancient red or gold dragon; it is otherwise impervious to damage. The statue containing the gemstone is a Medium object with AC 17, 40 hit points, and immunity to all damage except force damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In addition to his {@item staff of power}, Cassiok carries a spellbook bound in green slaad hide. It contains the spells Cassiok has prepared.

entries.name: 40. Lynnorax's Lair

entries: {@b Ceiling}. This room has a 40-foot-high, domed ceiling.
{@b Dracolich}. Lynnorax, an {@creature adult blue dracolich}, faces the double door to the east and exhales lightning in that direction as soon as it sees intruders.
{@b Pillars}. The four pillars that buttress the ceiling are carved out of black crystal and inscribed with arcane runes.
Lynnorax fights without fear, knowing that its phylactery (hidden in area 39) will preserve its life force if its skeletal body is destroyed.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals auras of abjuration magic around the crystal pillars, which grant the dracolich a damage threshold of 40. While in this room, the dracolich doesn't take damage from any single source unless that damage is equal to or greater than its damage threshold, in which case it takes the damage as normal. Damage that fails to meet or exceed the dracolich's damage threshold is magically negated by the pillars. Each time the pillars negate damage to the dracolich, their arcane runes glow brightly.
The dracolich loses the pillars' protection it leaves the room, so it prefers to fight here.
Each pillar is a Huge object with AC 13, 60 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Destroying a pillar reduces the dracolich's damage threshold by 10.

entries.name: 41. Shadowdusk Vault
entries: The Shadowdusks store their family's wealth here. The walls climb 15 feet vertically before angling inward, coming to a point 30 feet above the floor. The room's contents are as follows:
{@b Hoard}. Treasure is piled in the middle of the room.
{@b Statues}. Three statues stand in shallow alcoves. Each depicts a monstrously warped humanoid.
Each statue is roughly 6 feet tall and shows a human figure in robes, standing with arms outstretched. Each one has been warped by the power of the Far Realm:

items: The western statue has a mass of tentacles where a normal creature's head would be.

The face of the southern statue has been replaced with a chisel-toothed maw, and its arms resemble oily pseudopods. The head of the eastern statue has begun to flow and melt, but it is still recognizable as Halaster.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The treasure hoard consists of the following:

items: Three gemstones amid the coins: a topaz (500 gp), a star ruby (1,000 gp), and a jacinth (5,000 gp)
A tiny, incandescent blue sphere easily mistaken for a magic gemstone (actually an {@item ioun stone, insight||ioun stone of insight})
A child's rocking horse, half scorched by fire, with a gold music box (750 gp) tucked in a small compartment under the hinged saddle

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: Any humanoid member of the Shadowdusk family killed on this level returns as a {@creature will-o'-wisp} unless certain precautions are taken (see "{@area Exploring This Level|a8e|x}").

If Zalthar and Dezmyr are destroyed, they eventually re-form as death knights are wont to do. Their ambition and hatred burn too fiercely for them to be able to give up their dreams of conquest, and they are too corrupted by the Far Realm to be redeemed.

If they return to find the rest of their family destroyed, the death knights expand their hatred to include the adventurers who dared oppose them. Out of desperation, the twins try to forge alliances with other denizens of Undermountain, such as the drow of House Auvryndar or House Freth, the mind flayers of Seadeeps ({@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}), or the cult of Shar in Vanrakdoom ({@adventure level 18|WDMM|18}). If no such allies remain, Dezmyr and Zalthar look deep into the Underdark and the Far Realm, drawing forth aberrant horrors by offering them promises of a new life in Undermountain.

data.name: Level 23: Mad Wizard's Lair
entries: Halaster makes his home in the lowest level of Undermountain, which is optimized for four characters of 17th level or higher. Characters who defeat the monsters on this level should gain enough XP to reach 20th level.

entries.name: Who Dwells Here?
entries: In addition to Halaster, two of the Mad Mage's apprentices reside on this level: {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} and {@creature Trobriand|WDMM}.

entries.name: Halaster Blackcloak
entries: If the adventurers have made their way to this level, Halaster is equal parts impressed and curious. He is ready to grant the characters an audience, having kept an eye on their progress. True to the nature that earned him the moniker "Mad Mage," Halaster's demeanor toward the characters can change on a whim. He might alternate between seeming furious, baffled, annoyed, amused—or simply bored, depending on what the characters have accomplished before reaching this level. See {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25} for more information on the Mad Mage.

If the characters and their actions support Halaster's current goal (see "{@area Halaster's Goals|019|x}"), the Mad Mage is not necessarily hostile. For example, if his primary goal is to find an apprentice, Halaster has kept an eye on any arcane spellcasters in the party. He might suggest that those characters prove their worth by surviving the Mad Wizard's Lair and "freeing up" an apprenticeship by eliminating {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} or {@creature Trobriand|WDMM}. If this is done, Halaster is willing to take on an appropriate character as a new apprentice. Halaster has no sentimental attachment toward his apprentices, and he often enjoys secretly tormenting them.

entries.name: Arcturia
entries: {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} is a lich and a master of transmutation magic. She has altered her form dramatically over the years, now appearing more alive than undead. Gossamer wings sprout from her shoulders, and bone spurs jut from her forearms and elbows.
If the characters destroyed her phylactery on {@area level 14|783|x}, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} attacks them on sight. She has no beef with them otherwise.

entries.name: Trobriand the Metal Mage
entries: {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} specializes in the creation of magical constructs. Characters who have passed through the upper levels might have encountered some of his creations.

Fed up with the frailty of the flesh, {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} has transferred his spirit into the body of a specially prepared iron golem. This merging of spirit and metal has done nothing to improve his sanity, however.

entries.name: The Dungeon
entries: Locations in the dungeon portion of this level (areas 1 through 21) are keyed to map 23. No tunnels or staircases connect this dungeon complex to the upper levels of Undermountain. Characters arrive in {@area area 1|b1a|x} after passing through a gate in Shadowdusk Hold ({@area area 35 on level 22|af8|x}).

entries.name: 1. No Retreat

entries: {@b Arch}. The north wall is set with a stone arch, its keystone bearing Halaster's visage whose animated eyes follow any creature that approaches the arch. Carved into the wall above the keystone is a sigil.

{@b Statue}. An alcove to the south contains a life-size, painted stone statue of Halaster perched atop a 4-foot-tall granite plinth like a vulture, squatting with arms outstretched and fingers curled like talons, as though ready to leap down and claw at anyone who stands before it (see "{@area Halaster Statue|b1d|x}" below).

{@b Frescoes}. Six 10-foot-square painted frescoes adorn the walls around the arch: two flanking the arch on the north wall, two side by side on the west wall, and two side by side on the east wall. Each fresco displays a magically animated image of Halaster performing one or more mundane activities: stretching and yawning, juggling rods, sweeping the floor with a broom, trying to escape from a straitjacket, doing handstands, and shadowboxing.
{@b Secret Door}. Hidden behind the fresco that depicts Halaster stretching and yawning is a secret door.

Targeting an animated fresco with a {@spell dispel magic} spell has no effect other than to cause Halaster's image to silently mock the spell's caster. The images become motionless while in the area of an antimagic field.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 22
entries: The sigil inscribed above the arch is Halaster's personal rune. Both it and the face carved into the keystone are harmless.

Halaster can open the gate for 1 minute by touching the arch. The gate cannot otherwise be opened from this side. A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 35 on level 22|af8|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the gate located there.

entries.name: Halaster Statue
entries: Anytime a creature other than Halaster tries to cast a spell in this room, the statue's arms animate and perform the quick series of somatic gestures needed to cast {@spell counterspell}. After casting its spell, the statue reverts to its inanimate state until triggered again. The counterspell attempt succeeds automatically.

The statue is a Large object with AC 17, 50 hit points, and immunity to all damage except force damage. The statue falls to pieces and loses its spellcasting ability if it is reduced to 0 hit points. Destroying the statue triggers a {@spell magic mouth} spell; the mouth appears amid the shattered remains and says, "Is this the end of {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM}? Ha! I think not."

entries.name: 2. Reversed Library
entries: Everything in this room is upside down because gravity in the room is magically reversed. The room is furnished thusly:
{@b Bookshelves}. The walls are lined with upside-down bookshelves, fully stocked with upside-down history books from the many parts of the world Halaster has explored.
{@b Desk}. In the middle of the 15-foot-high ceiling is an upside-down desk topped with a stack of tomes held between two golden, upside-down bookends shaped like bulettes bursting out of the ground.

The reverse gravity field can't be negated, though it is suppressed within an antimagic field. Unless anchored, held down, or affected by a {@spell fly} spell or similar magic, any creature or object that enters this room falls up toward the ceiling.

The desk is empty except for the array of nine books held between the bulette-shaped bookends. Eight of the books contain essays pertaining to the eight schools of magic, one book dedicated to each school. The cover and the pages of the ninth book appear blank.

Placing the other books in alphabetical order by school of magic between the bookends causes Halaster's rune to appear on the cover of the ninth book and spells to appear on its pages. This tome is one of Halaster's spellbooks (see "Treasure" below).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The gold bookends are worth 500 gp for the pair, while the eight books detailing the schools of magic are worth 100 gp each.

Halaster's spellbook contains the following spells: {@spell Bigby's hand}, {@spell color spray}, {@spell crown of madness}, {@spell enlarge/reduce}, {@spell fabricate}, {@spell false life}, {@spell gaseous form}, {@spell gust of wind}, {@spell hold monster}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell jump}, {@spell maze}, {@spell Otto's irresistible dance}, {@spell reverse gravity}, {@spell sleet storm}, and {@spell weird}.

entries.name: 3. Talking Heads
entries: This 10-foot-high room has wooden shelves covering the walls from floor to ceiling. Hundreds of wide-mouthed jars line the shelves, each containing a severed head floating in brine.

The heads in the jars are specimens that Halaster has collected throughout Undermountain: goblins, drow, kuo-toa, duergar, troglodytes, githyanki, mind flayers, and other creatures. Although detached from their bodies, the heads remain alive and sedate as a result of Halaster's magic. Tapping on a jar is enough to stir a head to consciousness. The heads speak only the languages they knew in life and have no recollection of how they ended up in their disembodied state. A character can prompt a head for information, which it's happy to provide. Each head shares one Undermountain secret determined by drawing a card from the Secrets Deck (see {@adventure appendix C|WDMM|27}). A head can also confirm that Halaster spends a lot of time on this level of Undermountain.
Removing a head from a jar or removing a jar from this room ends the magic that animates the head, which immediately dies.

entries.name: 4. Helmed Horrors
entries: Six {@creature Helmed Horror||helmed horrors} float in the alcoves marked H on map 23. These constructs attack intruders on sight and fly after those who flee.

entries.name: 5. Magical Repository

entries: {@b Ceiling}. This room has a 30-foot-high vaulted ceiling.
{@b Statues}. Four statues, each one carved to look like a 20-foot-high purple worm bursting up through the floor, fill the corners of the room. (These statues are harmless.)

{@b Dome}. A deep, 20-foot-high alcove in the north wall contains four {@creature Invisible Stalker||invisible stalkers} trapped inside an invisible, dome-shaped wall of force rising from the floor. (Any items that Halaster removed from the mine carts in {@area level 15, area 1|791|x}, lie on the floor inside the dome. The dome appears to contain nothing else.)

The dotted circle on map 23 marks the edge of the dome, which was created by a {@spell wall of force} spell made permanent by Halaster. The dome can't be dispelled by {@spell dispel magic}, but a {@spell disintegrate} spell destroys it, freeing the invisible stalkers within.

The invisible stalkers attack any creature other than Halaster that enters the dome using magic (such as a {@spell dimension door} or {@spell misty step} spell). They also attack if the dome is destroyed. The stalkers like to gang up on one opponent at a time.

entries.name: 6. Wizardly Wards
entries: A trapped hall (area 6a) guards two of Halaster's vaults (areas 6b and 6c).

entries.name: 6a. Lightning Pillars
entries: This two-chambered hall has a 20-foot-high ceiling supported by ten copper-plated pillars of iron. The pillars generate arcs of magic lightning, as well as bolts that leap from one pillar to another. Creatures standing outside the hall are safe, as are creatures within the 20-foot-square space marked on map 23. A creature that ends its turn in any other space in the hall is struck by lightning from the nearest pillar and must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A character who uses an action to study the pillars and succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check notices a pattern in the lightning discharges and gains advantage on saving throws made against the pillars. In addition, the character identifies the safe space in the middle of the hall.

entries.name: 6b. Angelic Shield
entries: Mounted on the door to this chamber is a bronze knocker shaped like Halaster's mad visage, his beard entwined around the knocker's ring-shaped handle. A tiny bronze plaque mounted below the knocker reads in Common, "Knock first before entering."

Using the knocker triggers a {@spell glyph of warding} spell cast at 8th level. The glyph creates a 20-foot-radius sphere of magical flame. Each creature in the area must make a DC 22 Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@dice 10d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The tiny glyph can be found on the backside of the knocker's handle with a successful DC 22 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

entries.name: Shield
entries: The room is empty except for a steel shield hanging on the south wall. The shield is cast in the form of a serene, angelic visage wreathed in bronze feathers.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic around the otherwise ordinary shield, inside which is trapped a {@creature pit fiend} named Kastzanedes. Any ability that detects the presence of fiends, such as a paladin's Divine Sense class feature, reveals the presence of such a creature bound within the shield.

If an {@spell identify} spell is cast on the shield, or if it is brought within 10 feet of its sister shield in {@area area 9b|b30|x}, the pit fiend is released. It appears within 5 feet of the shield's bearer or in the nearest unoccupied space. The freed pit fiend attacks any other creatures it can see, targeting celestials above all others.

While trapped in the shield, the pit fiend can communicate telepathically with the shield's wielder. It pretends to be a sentient magic item that is unwilling to disclose its secrets, trying to goad the characters into casting {@spell identify} on it. If that tactic doesn't work, the pit fiend tries to talk the shield's wielder into undertaking a quest to find its sister shield. The pit fiend suspects that the other shield is nearby, but does not know its location.

entries.name: 6c. Components Storeroom
entries: This room contains wooden trestle tables laden with material components for spells, including linen-wrapped slabs of butter, casks of licorice root shavings, bottles of snake tongues, a terrarium filled with glowworms, and wax-sealed jars of rotting eggs.

entries.name: 7. Teleportation Pillars
entries: Eight black marble pillars form a circle in this 20-foot-high room. Carved into each pillar is a symbol representing one of the eight schools of magic (Abjuration, Conjuration, Divination, Enchantment, Evocation, Illusion, Necromancy, and Transmutation).
The first time a character enters the circle of pillars, a {@spell magic mouth} spell activates on the floor and speaks the following riddle in Common before vanishing:
A crown festooned my dwarven brow.
I rest beneath the mountain now.
Who am I?
The answer is "Melair," the dwarf king who is buried on {@adventure level 6|WDMM|6}. The characters can use divination magic to determine the correct answer if they can't work it out.

Speaking Melair's name aloud while standing in the room causes the symbols on the pillars to glow bright colors. The symbols continue to glow for 1 minute. During that time, any creature that enters the area inside the pillars or starts its turn there is teleported to a similar location in {@area area 8|b2b|x}, along with anything it is wearing or carrying.

entries.name: 8. Teleportation Pillars
entries: Eight black marble pillars stand in a circle near the walls of this 20-foot-high room. A fist-sized yellow sapphire is embedded in each of the five easternmost pillars at a height of 10 feet, such that all five gemstones face inward. Each of the remaining three pillars, in the west side of the room, bears an empty indentation where a similar gem is meant to be placed. The three missing gems can be found in {@area area 17|b47|x}.

When all eight yellow sapphires are placed in their pillars, they glow brightly as the pillars' magic activates. Any creature that enters the area inside the pillars or starts its turn there is teleported to a similar location in {@area area 7|b2a|x}, along with anything it is wearing or carrying.
The sapphires can be pried from their fixtures, but removing even one of them deactivates the pillars.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The yellow sapphires are worth 1,000 gp each.

entries.name: 9. Vaults
entries: These chambers have 15-foot-high, flat ceilings.

entries.name: 9a. Hall of Staffs

entries: {@b Mosaics}. Tiled mosaics depicting a variety of magic staffs cover the walls. (Hidden behind a mosaic depicting a {@item staff of thunder and lightning} is a secret door.)
{@b Dead End}. Part of the eastern wall has been obliterated, leaving behind a jagged dead-end tunnel.

The mosaic of the {@item staff of thunder and lightning}, unlike the others, is cracked and scorched. If this section of wall is targeted by any effect that deals lightning or thunder damage, the secret door hidden behind the mosaic swings opens into {@area area 9b|b30|x}. {@spell Knock} spells and similar magic have no effect on the secret door, but a {@spell disintegrate} spell destroys it. No amount of physical force can open the secret door from this side, but the door opens easily from {@area area 9b|b30|x}.

entries.name: 9b. Diabolical Shield
entries: Hanging on the west wall of this otherwise empty 15-foot-high room is a steel shield cast in the form of a scowling devil's face wreathed by bronze flames.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic around the otherwise ordinary shield, inside which is trapped a {@creature deva} named Aryx. While trapped in the shield, Aryx can't communicate with anyone. Any ability that detects the presence of celestials, such as a paladin's Divine Sense class feature, reveals the presence of such a creature bound within the shield. If a {@spell dispel evil and good} spell is cast on the shield, or if the shield comes within 10 feet of a fiend, the deva is released, appearing within 5 feet of the shield or in the nearest unoccupied space. Once freed, the deva uses its {@spell detect evil and good} spell to determine if there are any evil creatures in its presence. If so, Aryx attacks them, targeting fiends above all others.

Aryx was sent by Tyr, the god of justice, to talk some sense into {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}, the fallen planetar on level 21. Before Aryx could approach {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}, however, Halaster trapped the deva in the shield. Aryx must complete its mission before it can return to Tyr's heavenly realm. If the characters claim to have killed {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} or helped the planetar achieve atonement, the deva uses a {@spell commune} spell to verify as much. If the characters speak the truth, Aryx shows its gratitude by granting each party member a {@i blessing of health} (see "{@book Supernatural Gifts|DMG|8|Supernatural Gifts}" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}). If the characters have not yet dealt with the fallen planetar on {@adventure level 21|WDMM|21}, Aryx offers to fight alongside the party until such time as it can leave this level and complete its mission, provided the characters aren't predominantly evil. If the characters help Aryx defeat {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} later on, the deva shows its gratitude by bestowing upon them the {@i blessing of health}.

entries.name: 10. Arcane Display
entries: These areas have 20-foot-high, arched ceilings.

entries.name: 10a. Zigzagging Gallery
entries: Characters who make a loud racket in this hall attract the seven {@creature Flameskull||flameskulls} in {@area area 10b|b34|x}. The features of this hall are as follows:
{@b Chandeliers}. Radiant crystal chandeliers levitate near the ceiling.
{@b Paintings}. Paintings line the walls. They come in many sizes and have gilded frames.

The hall contains three chandeliers, their locations marked on map 23. Each chandelier magically sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. A chandelier can bear up to 150 pounds of additional weight before falling. Casting {@spell dispel magic} on a chandelier causes it to go dark and fall to the floor with a loud crash.

The paintings are stuck to the walls with {@item sovereign glue} and require {@item universal solvent} to remove without destroying them. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of illusion magic around each painting, of which there are hundreds. Half of them are portraits of Halaster, looking as demented as ever in his {@item robe of eyes}. About a quarter of them are portraits of other wizards (former apprentices). The remainder are paintings of unknown people with the heads of small beasts (badgers, mice, rabbits, birds, fish, and so forth). The paintings' eyes (including the eyes on Halaster's robes) seem to follow visitors as they move through the hall—a minor magical illusion.

entries.name: 10b. Shield Trap

entries: {@b Flameskulls}. Unless they were drawn to {@area area 10a|b32|x}, seven {@creature Flameskull||flameskulls} float here, their green flames the only sources of light in this room.
{@b Decor}. More paintings like the ones in {@area area 10a|b32|x} line the walls. A golden shield encrusted with gemstones hangs on the south wall among the paintings.

Halaster made the flameskulls from the skulls of wizards who tried and failed to become his apprentices. They attack intruders on sight, bombarding them with {@spell fireball} spells in the first round of combat. The flameskulls pursue intruders that flee, using their {@spell mage hand} spells to open doors if needed.

Hanging on a stone peg that juts from the wall, the gold-plated shield is etched with arcane runes. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of necromancy magic radiating from the shield. A character who examines the runes and succeeds on a DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check can ascertain that the runes give the shield the magical ability to trap creatures inside it.

Any creature that touches the shield must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or become trapped inside it, along with everything the creature is wearing or carrying. The shield displays a faint image of the trapped creature in its reflective outer surface. The shield can trap only one creature at a time. Whenever it traps a new creature, the shield releases its current prisoner, which appears in an unoccupied space as close to the shield as possible.

A creature trapped in the shield can do nothing except attempt a DC 18 Charisma saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a successful save, the creature is released and appears in an unoccupied space as close to the shield as possible. On a failed save, the creature takes 31 ({@dice 7d8}) necrotic damage. If this damage reduces the trapped creature to 0 hit points, its body is destroyed as its soul is released into the afterlife.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The shield is worth 7,500 gp and can be used as an ordinary shield, but battle damage might reduce its value as an art object at your discretion.

entries.name: 11. Trobriand's Workshop
entries: These areas have 20-foot-high, flat ceilings.
{@b Scrap Metal}. Workbenches lining the east and west walls are covered in metal scraps.
{@b Unfinished Construct}. In the center of the room is a Huge scorpion constructed from metal. (This is an incomplete scaladar that is not active.)
{@b Guards}. Two {@creature scaladar|WDMM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) guard this room and won't leave it under any circumstances.
{@b Secret Door}. The walls, floor, and ceiling are covered in 5-foot-square steel tiles. One tile conceals a secret door in the east wall at floor level.

entries.name: 11c. Trobriand's Body
entries: The body of a frail man in dark robes lies atop a stone slab near the south wall. The man has long, wavy hair and a thick beard the color of iron, and he wears a metal ring on the index finger of his left hand.

Characters who have seen images of {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} know that the body lying on the slab is his. After {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} successfully transferred his spirit to an iron golem (see {@area area 13|b40|x}), his body was placed here by the scaladar servants that guard {@area area 11b|b3a|x}. The body is in stasis but can be attacked normally. It is {@condition unconscious} and has AC 12 and 99 hit points. Without its spirit, the body is an empty vessel, and {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} is unaware of what's happening to it while his spirit resides elsewhere. Destroying this body prevents {@creature Trobriand|WDMM}'s spirit from returning to it when the spirit is forced to vacate the golem in {@area area 13|b40|x}, effectively killing the Metal Mage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} wears a black metal ring on the index finger of his left hand that controls scaladar and overrides all other rings that have that property. It functions only within Undermountain (see the "{@creature Scaladar|WDMM}" entry in {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}).

entries.name: 12. Gate to the Stone Bridge

entries: {@b Standing Gate}. Two 15-foot-tall standing stones are positioned near the west wall of this 20-foot-high room.
{@b Bas-Relief}. Spanning the wall behind the standing stones is a bas-relief depicting an armored dwarf with a greataxe fighting a hill giant atop a long, flat bridge.
